news politics people-hartlepool-say-keir-starmer-"" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice The people of Hartlepool had a stark message for Labour leader Keir Starmer on Friday: You have forgotten your heartland - and neglected the traditional aposworking classapos voter.The Mirror did a tour of the town and its historic headland, where the statue of our very own Andy Capp stands proudly swathed in a rainbow scarf with a message of thanks to NHS staff for their work during the pandemic.Traditional Labour voters in the seat which the party had held since its creation in  admitted Andyaposs creator Reg Smythe, a Mirror legend and one of the townaposs most famous sons, would be aposturning in his graveapos as Boris Johnson celebrated victory.Conservative Jill Mortimer won the by-election with more than half of the votes cast, a swing from Labour of almost  percent. She took , votes, a majority of , over Labouraposs Dr Paul Williams. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section The heavens opened shortly after Johnson embarked on his victory tour here, doing a photo call with farmeraposs daughter Jill on the marina. Before today, the very words aposConservative MP for Hartlepoolapos would have seemed impossible. It does not rain but it pours for Labour as the Prime Minister rejoiced in yet another demolition job on the former aposRed Wallapos of Labour-held constituencies.Peter Cook, , a lelong Labour voter before the  General election, a trade unionist and former shop steward, said: The biggest mistake Labour made here was when they brought in a rejected former MP from Stockton who had supported Remain and attacked people who wanted to come out of Europe. I was disgusted, Brexit was the big issue for me - the vast majority of the town rejected staying in Europe.Pardon my French, I think Boris Johnson has made a right b**** of it especially for the fishing industry in this country. I had previously voted Labour, but I donapost knowI will vote for them again in my letime. And he warned Keir Starmer that he needed to get out of the Westminster bubble - and fast. I am not interested in Borisapos wallpaper, he said. We need to look at where things are going wrong.  There was a time when two steelworks here, we had engineering, we used to make things. Not any more. We canapost let China produce everything. We want aposcan doapos politicians who get things done -Labour had good ideas, people would vote for them. His next door neighbour on the historic town wall, William Crask, , a dad-of-two and production operator, had the same message. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  Labour has lost its way, he said. I am a working man, and the fact is that they donapost represent me anymore. They are for public servants, the middle class, people on benefits. Butyou are a working class person, in a normal job, they just donapost seem to care. I did not vote Labour last time when I had before, because I was for Brexit.  But it is not just about that, they donapost talk about investment, they donapost seem to have any policies, they donapost have a vision. Boris makes mistakes but he is just himself, and people donapost seem too worried about his faults.I voted for Tony Blair Labour went wrong with Ed instead of David Miliband.It was all downhill from there. The Labour party is trying to please everybody, and pleasing nobody.  Brexit is done, gone, and we need to move on from that. We need jobs, investment, not just all mouth and no action. Actions speak louder than words. In her victory speech, Jill Mortimer warned Labour had taken local people for granted for too longapos. Many agreed with that view, and spoke of the work of Tees mayor Ben Houchen in bringing investment to the area. Elizabeth Maughan, , a mum-of-three who works in a local newsagent, did not vote for Labour this time because she was so aposdisillusionedapos.  We have so much anti-social behaviour where we live, people smashing windows, and I am working and paying full council tax, she said. I have always voted Labour - my mother would be turning in her grave - but they have not done anything for Hartlepool. I could not vote Tory mind. Outside the Pot House pub, a popular spot with beautul views out over the town harbour, there were many who had turned Tory, however. Frank Boagey, , a retired steel erector who paid his union dues during a -year career, turned his back on Labour for the first time in  after lelong support.  All my family were fishermen, there was no way I was going to vote against Brexit, he said. This is not a dictatorship. The people of Hartlepool voted to leave the EU and Labour would not go with the majority view, which is what you do in a democracy. Mandelson was an embarrassment for me and so were the last two Labour MPs. If you had given Peter Mandelson a pin, he could not have found Hartlepool on the map before he came here and now he is Lord Mandelson of Hartlepool, it really is a joke. They kept on dropping people in here who know nothing about the place, taking the voters for granted.  I was a trade unionist for  years and voted Labour for  years and suddenly thought aposwhat have they done for me apos Retired local Government officer Edith Ward, , a great grandmother, was one of the few dissenting voices. But she was not surprised that Labour lost, and urged the party to do more to win back the traditional working class voters. I think people have forgotten all the huge mistakes made at the start of the pandemic, the thousands of lives lost as a result of those mistakes, she said. I voted against Boris. But Labour have got to try harder to win this back, and prove they are better than people think right now.  They do need to make a change. Her friend Ann Murray, , a retired office clerk, great grandmother and former Labour voter, went for a local candidate as she felt more needed to be done aposfor the North eastapos. Independent Sam Lee took her vote and , others, with . percent overall, as Tories took huge gains from the , who voted Brexit last time. Hartlepool-born Christine Appleyard, , on a visit to see her school friend Julie Sladen, , described the result as a aposbloody tragedyapos.

title: airport delays summer could 15
story: NewsAirport delays this summer could be  times longer than normal, Border Chief warnsBorder Force director Paul Lincoln has advised passengers to face increased delays at "each stage" of their journey. Grant Shapps has announced  countries are on the UK green listmirrorShareCommentsByLuke Powell:,  MAY NewsThere could be y delays for those heading abroad this summer " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeTravellers should expect longer waiting times at UK borders as the Government switches to a traffic light system for international travel. Border Force director Paul Lincoln said passengers must accept there will be increased delays at each stage of their journey, with staff required to check % of all travellers coming through. His comments came as Transport Secretary Grant Shapps announced that  countries - including Portugal, Gibraltar and Israel - would be added to the Governmentaposs green list for travel. From May , people in England will be able to visit those destinations without having to enter quarantine on their . But Mr Lincoln told a Downing Street press conference on Friday that the introduction of health checks at the border meant it now takes, on average, five to  minutes for staff to process each passenger arriving into the UK. He said: For the time being, passengers will need to accept an increase in the time taken at each stage of their journey. It currently takes a Border Force officer five to  minutes to complete all the necessary checks, which means that even for the most compliant passenger, it might take  or  times longer to process than before, compared to around  seconds. Where people do not have the correct paperwork, it can and has taken considerably longer, including when we need to serve fixed penalty notices for non-compliance.

will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeArchie Mountbatten-Windsor aposspeaks with a distinct American accentapos and chats with the Queen over Zoom, according to sources. Itaposs thought that the Queen logged on to wish her great-grandson Archie a happy birthday, when he turned two, earlier this week.Since Prince Harry and his American we Meghan Markle made the move across the pond to Calornia, their son, Archie, he has been keeping in touch with members of the royal family via video calls.In the coupleaposs interview with Oprah back in March, Harry revealed that he had spoken to the Queen more in the last year than he had for many, many years. My grandmother and I have a really good relationship. And an understanding. And I have a deep respect for her, he added. Harry reportedly also met privately with the Queen twice when he ed to the UK in April for his grandfather, the Duke of Edinburghaposs funeral. But Archie stayed at home with Meghan, who was too heavily pregnant to travel.  According to the Mail, officials at the palace were left feeling uncomfortable this week because they didnapost have an up-to-date picture of Meghan and Harryaposs son Archie to accompany his birthday messages on social media.Instead they had to use photos from just after he was born or from his official christening. A source said: The truth is the Prince of Wales has barely seen his grandson twice since he was born. In fact every member of Harry’s family can easily count on one hand the number of times they saw Archie after he was born and before the family left the UK. It’s a very sad situation. The source reportedly stressed that no one is directly to blame for the lack of family connections. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex sensationally quit the royal family last year and moved first to Vancouver Island on Canadaaposs west coast and then to Los Angeles, where they now reside. The pandemic has meant that they have been unable to make social visits toto the UK although Harry was back in Windsor briefly for his grandfatheraposs funeral. Which is why the Queen and other family members have mostly had to make do with video calls.

title: boy eight needed kidney transplant
story: NewsBoy, eight, needed kidney transplant after catching E.coli during country walkLeo McFaulds needed a kidney transplant from his mum after he and brother Samuel, aged four, became ill with the disease - which affects the blood and blood vessels, resulting in anaemia and kidney failuremirrorShareCommentsBySarah Ward:,  MAY NewsLeo McFaulds needed a kidney transplant from his mum after he and brother Samuel, aged four, became ill " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice An eight-year-old boy needed lesaving surgery after he and his brother caught E.coli - which their parents believe may have been from a countryside walk in the Highlands.Leo McFaulds needed a kidney transplant from his mum after he and brother Samuel, aged four, became ill with the disease.E. coli causes Haemolytic Uraemic Syndrome- an illness which affects the blood and blood vessels, resulting in anaemia and kidney failure. The siblings became seriously ill in May  which their parents believe may have occurred after a walk in the Scottish Highlands, reports the Daily Record.  The family, from Elgin, Moray, relocated to Glasgow where the boys were treated at the Royal Hospital for Children- one of only two childrenaposs kidney transplant centres in the UK able to maintain a full schedule of renal transplants throughout the pandemic.Samuel made a recovery after being treated with dialysis. But Leo was in hospital for more than two months before being moved onto three times weekly kidney dialysis in August and medics knew he would need a renal transplant. Mum Louise was a perfect match and the transplant took place on February . It was an awful time for our family as it came on so suddenly.  Thankfully Samuel recovered relatively quickly, but Leo went from being a typical happy, healthy boy, who played in the garden with his brother and attended school, to being completely hospital-bound and unable to fully engage with normal le. But his bravery and optimism through this has been inspiring. I was naturally over the moon when we found I was a match, and despite the pandemic, from then on everything in the transplant work up process seemed to go like clock-work. Leo will always have kidney disease, and Samuel and myself will have follow up for some time to come. We know there will be bumps in the road ahead, but to look back six months, to compare where we are now itaposs a miracle really. Leo now has his le back and weaposll be counting the small milestones - going back to school, going swimming and maybe even a holiday - as victories and we will never take any of these happy family moments for granted in future.  Dr Ben Reynolds, consultant paediatric nephrologist at NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, who leads the transplant service, said: It is fantastic to see Leo recovering well and full of energy again, full of eight- year-old mischief and silliness. At RHC weaposre lucky to be one of only two childrenaposs kidney transplant centres in the UK able to maintain a full schedule of renal transplants throughout the pandemic. This is so important for children like Leo where there is a well matched donor, and the operation means we can get them off dialysis and back to as normal a le, as quickly as possible. title: delivery mans rapid covid test
story: AdvertorialDelivery mans rapid Covid test outside hospice could have saved livesRegular rapid testing at home is a quick and easy way to help stop the spread of Covid- and protect the people around youmirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialRegular testing now seen as vital to stop the spread of Covid-Alex had no symptoms when he tested positive for Covid- back in February. Around a third of people with coronavirus show no symptoms, so can infect others without even knowing they’ve been ill. Rapid testing is a vital tool to make sure people know when to self isolate so they break the chain of transmission. Alex, , from Hemel Hempstead, works for JamVans, a removal company that provides Covid- tests for its employees. He was experiencing no symptoms at all when he tested positive for Covid. “We move people’s homes on a daily basis, and also have a delivery contract with a local hospice – it has about  charity stores, and we help them move all the stock,” says Alex. “One morning before work I did a rapid Covid- test outside the hospice, then sat in my van waiting for the results. I’d done a few of these tests, and thought it would be fine as I didn’t have a single symptom – but then the test came back positive.”  “I spoke to the hospice on the phone from outside the building, and they told me I had to go for a PCR test. My company booked me in with a private firm and I went straight there. Our company policy is that we have to wear a mask in people’s houses and throughout our offices, and I stick to the guidelines as much as I can, so at first I thought the rapid flow test must be wrong. But within an hour, I was told I definitely had Covid. I couldn’t quite believe it.” Alex was able to isolate straightaway, ensuring he wasn’t spreading Covid to any vulnerable people he came into contact with. “I stopped working to self-isolate on full pay, and still didn’t develop any symptoms at all,” he says. “Without the test, I definitely would have carried on working, which is why it’s so important to have regular tests, evenyou haven’t got any symptoms. I had the virus and I felt fine, but imagineI’d given it to my parents, my grandparents or my colleagues  “If I’m driving between  charity shops, with three or four people in each shop, I could have been quite a spreader. I would have put a lot of people at risk, who may not be as young and healthy as I am – you never know who you’re passing it on to. It might sound dramatic, but in my case, taking the test could have saved lives. I haven’t had the jab yet, but I will as soon as I can – and I’ll still be taking two tests a week.Get into the testing habit More than half the adults in the UK have had at least one dose of Covid vaccination and lockdown restrictions are beginning to ease. But the virus is still out there and around a third of all the people who are infected do not show any symptoms. Regular rapid testing is vital to break the chain of transmission – now all adults are advised to do two tests a week. Rapid testing kits are free and you can do them at home, with results appearing within just  minutes. If you test positive, you’ll be able to isolate straightaway rather than risk spreading Covid to others. Millions of people have already made regular home testing part of their routine, as secondary school children and their parents have been able get free tests since February, but now everyone is encouraged to play their part. Every test helps to put your mind at rest and helps protect people around you as the country moves out of lockdown. Around one in three people with coronavirus has no symptoms. Rapid Covid-tests are for people who aren’t showing symptoms. If you’re showing symptoms , order a PCR test. Test twice a week, or every three or four days: it’s the best way to catch a case of Covid- at the point it becomes highly infectious.If you test positive you should self-isolate immediately and visit nhs.uk get-tested or call  to order a PCR test that will confirm the result.If you test negative, you must still follow the Hands, Face, Space and Fresh Air rules to minimise the spread of Covid-. Rapid tests are easy to use and give results within  minutes. It’s important to report your results online straightaway, whether the test is positive, negative or even void. It’s easy to do at gov.uk report-covid-result or by calling .More than m rapid tests have been taken since October , and hundreds of thousands of positive cases among people with no symptoms have been picked up. Information from the rapid tests is kept anonymous, and scientists use it to spot patterns and outbreaks more quickly and accurately, helping to reduce the risk of future lockdowns. Even though you might have already had one or two doses of vaccine, there’s a chance you could still give Covid to someone , as no vaccine is  per cent effective. So it’s vital to test twice weekly as well as continuing to follow social distancing guidance, washing hands, wearing a face covering and letting fresh air in. Rapid Covid- tests are suitableyou have no symptoms of Covid .“Remember, around a third of people with coronavirus have no symptoms, but could be spreading it to others without knowing,” says GP Dr Amir Khan. “Rapid testing is effective at detecting people who are infectious and enabling us to find Covid- cases that we otherwise would not know about. This helps us in our efforts to stop the spread of the virus. Testing regularly even when you have no symptoms means we can keep infection levels low and our country safe, and the good thing is they give a result within  minutes.” And, as Dr Khan notes, the tests are very reliableyou do them correctly. “Testing ourselves for coronavirus using rapid Covid- tests is vital in keeping ourselves and others safe from coronavirus and keeping infection rates in our communities low. When done correctly, the tests are at least . per cent specic, which means the risk of  positives is extremely low – less than one in a thousand. This means it is a very good test.”‘All I had was a mild sore throat’ Kim Tobin, from Southend, Essex, works in a supermarket and had a positive Covid- test in January  Routine rapid testing in the workplace helped Kim, , discover she had Covid, even though she was showing no symptoms. Without the test, she could have spread it to her workmates and customers.“I had a very, very mild sore throat, just a little scratch and that was it,” she says. “I didn’t even think anything of it. I was all dressed for work, ready to go. Then I went and had the test, and after  minutes the lady who had done it came up to me and said, ‘You need to go home right now because you’ve got it – you’ve tested positive.’”

title: inside couples homemade pub garden
story: NewsInside couples homemade pub in their garden they took just four weeks to buildAfter nearly a year of lockdowns, Russell Adey and Kate were missing their regular drinking hole and wanted a project to focus on to distract from mental health strugglesmirrorShareCommentsByRia NewmanGraeme Murray:,  MAY NewsA couple has transformed a shed in their garden into a pub in just four weeks " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA couple have transformed a shed into a traditional pub in just four weeks. Russell Adey, , and we Kate, , were regulars at their local hostelry and visited with friends several times a week. But after nearly a year of lockdowns, they were missing their regular drinking hole and wanted a project to focus on to distract from mental health struggles. They decided to create a traditional pub in their garden which they have dubbed the Adey Arms. Russell pulled up part of the lawn at the bottom of their garden and laid slabs ready for a structure to be erected.What do you think  Have your say in comments belowThey then purchased a £, summer house, which they liken to a big shed, and it was delivered and put up in mid-March this year. The couple from Stourbridge, West Midlands, then painted the exterior and flooring, before insulating and plaster-boarding the walls. A local electrician install the electrics before the couple started the decorating process, hanging wallpaper and sourcing second-hand furniture.The bar, table, benches and log burner were made by a local carpenter, and the couple found the fridges, beer pumps and soft furnishings on eBay and Facebook Marketplace.No pub would be complete without its own merchandise, so they also ordered a sign for the door and personalised beer mats - all emblazoned with aposThe Adey Armsapos.  For extra fun, they added a projector and big screen for movie nights and football matches. The family-friendly garden pub has a table area for their children, Archie, , and nine-year-old Tilly. In total the couple spent £, and the pub was finished in mid-April, taking just four weeks to complete. We soon started missing the pub when lockdown started, and with home-schooling the kids my we was desperate for one, Russell, who works as a sales manager, said. Me and Kate were really suffering with our mental health during lockdown and decided we needed a project of some sort to focus our energies on, that would be fun to do and could be a lasting reminder of how important our friends and family are to us. The fact we werenapost able to see them all had really hit home to us, so we decided to build our own pub. Once the idea was in place, Kate started a mood board and they got to work designing the whole thing. Russell said: We were adamant that we wanted to buy local and source everything from local businesses, or recycle by buying second-hand things - which would keep the cost down as well. Businesses had suffered so much with the pandemic so we wanted to give something back and try and do our bit for the local community. Once completed, the pub was spacious enough to have three separate seating areas - tall stools, a corner table to seat six and a miniature table and stools for the kids. The family opted for classic pub decor, with exposed brick wallpaper, wooden finishes and even traditional features including stuffed animal heads.  In a fun twist, they also framed a picture of the Queen covered in tattoos. After finishing installing and decorating the pub, the family were inseparable from their new watering hole. Russell said: The bar was finished in mid-April and we have been in it ever since.We have a coffee machine and soft drinks so weaposre not always drinking alcohol.Now we have the pub I canapost see us going back to our old haunt. The drinks are cheaper and we now have everything we need at the bottom of the garden, so thereaposs no need to go anywhere . We also donapost need a designated driver anymore as we can just stumble up to the house. Our family absolutely love it in there - it saved us during lockdown at a time where there didnapost seem to be anything to look forward to. We are so proud of it and what it represents. The couple are hoping to share their new space with loved ones as soon as possible. Russell said: We canapost wait to invite people round to enjoy it with us as soon as restrictions are lted.

title: irish cafe owners sent anonymous
story: NewsOwners of Irish cafe in Coventry stunned by anonymous IRA note in postOTooles Cafe in Earlsdon, Coventry, posted about the incident on its Facebook page and was immediately inundated with support from disgusted locals, all voicing their supportmirrorShareCommentsByNaomi de Souza:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsOTooles Cafe in Earlsdon, Coventry, is a popular spot in the city, famed for their Irish breakfasts " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe owners of an Irish cafe which received an anonymous note accusing them of displaying aposIRA flagsapos have spoken of their shock at the unsettling incident. OaposTooles Cafe in Earlsdon, Coventry, is a popular spot in the city, famed for their Irish breakfasts and freshly baked goods. Opened in , the cafe displays the Irish flag and Irish flag bunting above their seating area. But on the morning of May , they received an anonymous typed note that said: How long are the IRA banners going to be there The Westwood Road venue posted about the incident on its Facebook page and was immediately inundated with support from disgusted locals, all voicing their support, reports Coventry Live.Writing on their Facebook page on Thursday May , owner Isobell Adams wrote: Firstly, please excuse what could be a long post. I received this through the post today, to say I am shocked is an understatement. I thought this nonsense was long behind us as a society. I have no IRA banners in my cafe. I have bunting that denotes the tricolour, the flag of Ireland. I have the Irish flag painted on my sign, that is all. I won’t give this any more credence. We have tried so hard to integrate with a fantastic community and we have been warmly received. This is so sad.Speaking to CoventryLive the day after the incident, owner Isobell Adams said: It came in with the ordinary post, itaposs hard to say, itaposs just quite unsettling really, when you look at it from face value itaposs all a bit silly, butyou feel this deeply, a why because I donapost have any paramilitary regalia and b how far are you prepared to take it  What might you do next  She added: I put the post up because I was so saddened by the whole thing, we have been so accepted by the whole Earlsdon community, and tried to show weaposre not just here for our benefit, weaposre here to be part of the community and do anything we can, so it all just felt a bit horrible, is the only word.OaposTooles opened in November , and like many in the hospitality industry, have faced an uphill battle to stay open during the pandemic.  Explaining the history behind the cafe, she explained OaposTooles is her motheraposs maiden name, and a nod to her family in County Mayo, who were known for their baking. Itaposs nothing fancy, just good Irish home cooking, and thataposs all this is for, a little nod to my mum, my Aunty Celia, a nod to them thataposs all it is, we make our own potato cakes, soda bread.Ms Adams said since the incident, the cafe has been busier than ever, with Earlsdon locals popping in with flowers and well wishes to show their support.The support from this community has been, I donapost even know how to put it into words, it really is humbling, I put the post up because I felt it ought to be shared, and I knew that the community were behind us, but to this degree  Theyaposve just been absolutely overwhelming, and itaposs just so so lovely. As far as Iaposm concerned that was yesterday, with the support weaposve got from the community Iaposm not going to dwell on someoneaposs negativity. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Coventry Irish Society also voiced their support for OaposTooles, writing on their page: We were very shocked to hear of the letter that OaposTooles Cafe received regarding the Irish flags on the building.We very much support OaposTooles Cafe in celebrating their heritage and those in and around the Earlsdon area. We are deeply saddened to see that this sort of intolerance has been displayed in Coventry when we are being celebrated as the City of Culture . Coventry residents were quick to voice their support for the cafe on its Facebook page, with more than  people commenting.

use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Prince William and Kate Middleton have learned lessons from Prince Harry and Meghan Markle as they really push towards being the future king and queenapos, a royal expert has said.Commentator Duncan Larcombe said the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have embarked on a rebranding as they look to ensure the survival of the Firm in the modern world.Earlier this week they changed the name of their @KensingtonRoyal Instagram page to the more informal @DukeandDuchessofCambridge, while adding a photo of themselves smiling.It follows the pair launching a YouTube channel and releasing a family video to mark their -year wedding anniversary on April . The couple also released a  second compilation video meeting royal fans. It begins with William pointing at the camera and saying: Be careful what you say now, because these guys are here filming everything. Kate laughs and says I know as the footage kicks in.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  “I honestly think they have embarked on a rebranding in the light of what effectively the importance of personality as well as position for the royals, Mr Larcombe told the Sun. “Harry and Meghan have shown that modern royalty will only surviveit is absolutely at the cutting edge of social media that their profiles play into the narrative of the cult of the celebrity. “William has decided now is really the time to really push them as a couple as well as the future king and queen.”  Since stepping back as senior royals, Harry and Meghan have often outshone other members of the family when it comes to news coverage.In order to bag multi-million pound deals with the likes of Netflix and Spoty, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have had to ramp up building a brand separate to the Firm itself in the last year. It comes after fellow royal commentator Daniela Elser said Kate had actually upstaged sister-in-law Meghan by nailing the social media game.  She said the Duchess was winning a royal power play thataposs set to change the crown forever, while the world is distracted by the Harry and Meghan Show. Writing for news.au, she said a case in point was an Easter video she posted.Rather than the obvious imagery associated with the time of year, the Cambridges instead went with a cheeky video of a chocolate egg being smashed in reverse.  The commentator added that Kateaposs skills as an amateur photographer have also helped in the coupleaposs social media transformation. Last weekend, the couple released a photo of daughter Princess Charlotte, taken by her mum in Norfolk, to mark her sixth birthday. And last July they did the same for first born Prince George when he turned seven.

will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeMeghan Markle and Prince Harry ripped up the royal rule book when it came to welcoming their son Archie, attracting praise from around the world for doing things their own way. While some people were disappointed that they couldnapost gather outside the hospital or see the traditional photos, the couple still included well-wishers by arranging a photocall at Windsor Castle and new dad Harry gave a spontaneous interview. But there was one aspect they legally had to share with the world - Archieaposs birth certicate. The document, like all birth certicates, was a matter of public record, regardless of your royal status. It revealed for the first time where Archie was born, the Portland Hospital, and also showed an interesting detail about Meghan - her official job title. The document lists her role as Princess of the United Kingdom. It left many fans scratching their heads, wondering why it said princess when Meghanaposs official title is Duchess. While she was given the title the Duchess of Sussex by the Queen on her wedding day, she is also technically a princess, just not in her own name. She is Her Royal Highness Princess Henry of Wales through her husband, Harry. The Duchess of Cambridge also listed princess under the job section part of the form on Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louisaposs birth certicates.  However there was further confusion around Archieaposs birth certicate in January when it emerged that Meghan and Harry changed it months after officially registering his birth. The couple removed Rachel Meghan from the aposmotheraposs nameapos section, leaving simple the Duchess of Sussex.Days after the changes were made, Harry and Meghan walked away from the Fab Four’s joint charity and had quit the Royal family within months.Some experts claimed it could be seen as a snub to Prince William and Kate, who have her name on George, Charlotte and Archieaposs unorm, however this was quickly rubbished by the couple.

title: mum finally gets neighbours after
story: NewsMum finally gets neighbours - after living alone on new build housing estate for  yearsLaura ODonnell, , has been surrounded by a building site ever since she moved into the former show home with no neighbours and only rats for companymirrorShareCommentsByOwen HughesBusiness correspondentKara ONeillReporter:,  MAY NewsLaura ODonnell with daughter Shannon Warren and son Harvey Woods " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum-of-five has been told she will be getting neighbours after a living on a housing estate for  years on her own. Laura OaposDonnell moved her family into one of the former show homes that had been built on a plot in Wrexham. At the time, the estate was still a building site, but she expected other houses to go up quickly, and anticipated that people would start to move in.Only, Harron Homes, who built Lauraaposs home in Heol Berwyn, Cefn Mawr, never went on to the develop the land, North Wales Live reports.The site remained unfinished, and Lauraaposs only neighbours were the rats that lived in the dirt and debris. But now, Laura and her children will finally have a community to live in, after the site was sold to Wales and West Housing and Anwyl Partnerships has been awarded the £.million development project for  homes. Itaposs believed in  months, Laura will be able to have chats over the garden fence with other residents - but she admits almost  years without neighbours means she has become a little anti-social. The -year-old, who has worked across the globe as a stunt woman for films and television programmes, said: When we moved in it was the only house built and it wasnapost the best location as the sewage works is nearby. The rest of the estate stayed as it was and I was looking out over a s***hole for years and weaposve had problems with rats here. With the homes getting built it will be quite nice for the children to finally have some friends here to play with, although Iaposm a bit anti-social once Iaposve finished work so in some ways itaposs been nice to be the only ones here! It will be a dficult  months during the build - Iaposve a son with ADHD who is susceptible to noise so it will be hard.

title: mum two took life hours
story: NewsMum-of-two took her own le hours after laughing with the kids in gardenJade Roberts, , suffered from anxiety, but her family said they were not aware of the true extent of what she was going through. She left a letter to her loved ones before her tragic death in AprilmirrorShareByCharlotte HadfieldChiara Fiorillo:,  MAY NewsJade Roberts died last month " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum-of-two took her own le hours after laughing and playing with her children in the garden. Jade Roberts, , suffered from anxiety, but her family said they were not aware of the true extent of what she was going through. The womanaposs cousin Karl Thomas, , said she sent him a video of herself playing with her children shortly before taking her own le.Jade, from Knotty Ash, Liverpool, left a letter to her loved ones before her tragic death in April, the Liverpool Echo reports.Her family paid tribute to her and described her as an unbelievable mum to her two sons - aged one and two years old.  Karl told the ECHO: She had all the people around her in the world but it just shows you, you can be surrounded by people and still feel alone.Itaposs so important that people do talk about how they are feeling instead of bottling things up. There need to be more s for people to do this I think, now more than ever. People have always been suffering but I think now itaposs coming from all angles and youaposre hearing about it more and more. A few hours before her death, Karl said Jade sent him a video of herself playing with her children in the garden. He said: You couldnapost see her because the camera was on the kids but sheaposs laughing in the video. She was an unbelievable mum. Every minute of the day was dedicated to her children. They are very happy and loving children and it speaks volumes of the person she was because kids are a blank canvas at the end of the day. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Karl said: She genuinely had the biggest heart of gold. She would do anything for anybody. She was always more worried about other people and tried to sort out other peopleaposs problems. Maybe that came from knowing how they felt and she didnapost want people feeling that way.A GoFundMe page set up by Jadeaposs friend Madina Wady to raise money for her two sons has raised over £, so far.Karl said the family have been blown away by the support they have received since Jadeaposs death.

title: nick faldo marries ex topless
story: NewsNick Faldo marries ex-topless dancer - golf heros fourth we and her seventh marriageEXCLUSIVE: Golfing legend Sir Nick Faldo has made a former topless dancer his fourth we - and its husband number seven for Lindsay De Marco, who has gone by  dferent names and had  addresses... and has drug convictionsmirrorShareCommentsByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsNick and Lindsay enjoying some sun " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSir Nick Faldo appears to have quietly got hitched again – to his former topless dancer girlfriend.Lindsay De Marco has now proudly changed her name to “Lindz Faldo” on her Facebook page.Sources say the -year-old, who met Faldo in , “revels” in being a Lady. It is Faldo’s fourth marriage and the seventh for Lindsay, who has gone by  dferent names and had  addresses. Randy Heine, who was married to her twice, wished Sir Nick, , “good luck”. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section A source told the Mirror: “Lindz has found everything she wants in a husband - handsome, kind, a knight and a multi-millionaire. What more can a girl ask for ” So close are the couple TV sources say Sir Nick was keen to include her in his CBS Sports show, called Faldo Formula. For her new Facebook profile picture, Lindsay uses a photo of herself with the six-time Major winner dressed as James Bond and her as his Bond girl. Faldo looks into the camera and says: “The name’s Faldo. Sir Nick Faldo. Cheers”. Lindsay then takes his drink off him before she rips off his dinner suit to show him dressed for golf. Two years ago, the Mirror revealed Faldo was dating Lindsay, who has drug convictions and once made her living “jiggling her boobs” in men’s faces. When approached by the Mirror, she denied having worked as a dancer. But ex-husband Randy – married to her twice – told how she performed as ‘Toni’ in the mid-s at his Florida club, Astra bar.  Randy had claimed she kept trading hubbies because she was “consumed” with climbing the social ladder. He offered to meet Faldo, worth around £million, saying: “I’d bring him up to date about how long his marriage might last and how much he’ll have to payit doesn’t work out,” he said. Randy and Lindsay got in trouble in  when she was a boss at one of his businesses, The Tobacco Emporium. It was was one of  stores in Florida raided by the FBI. Both were charged with drug offences, including possession of marijuana and selling drugs paraphernalia. Lindsay pleaded no contest and got a  fine and six months probation.  Two years later, in a federal court, she struck a deal and entered a guilty plea to one charge of “use of interstate conveyance to ship drug paraphernalia”. She receieved six months of house detention. By the time of her sentencing, Lindsay had wed Col Nicholas De Marco, as a “career officer” in the US Air Force. Although they orced, she reverted to using his surname at golfing events.  The fourth man she married was Thomas Bracken, and she then wed multi-millionaire Scott Sangalli. Faldo, who flits across the Atlantic with Lindsay from a £million bungalow in Florida to a riverside flat overlooking Windsor Castle has been in the rough in his personal le several times. His marriage to first we Melanie Rockall ended after four-and-a-half years. He then married Gill Bennett, with whom he had three kids. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBookings for Portugal have gone through the roof after the holiday hotspot was revealed as one of  countries on Englandaposs green list, a travel agency said.The southern European sun trap also saw Google searches sky rocket by over , percent in the  minutes after the list was first announced yesterday, according to reports.From May , people from England will be able to travel to those destinations selected without quarantining for two weeks onas the country continues to ease out of Covid lockdown. Thomas Cook said last night it had taken more bookings for trips to Portugal in one hour than in the whole of last month. The firmaposs head of PR David Child said jet-setters appeared posed, ready and waiting to go as Transport Secretary Grant Shapps announced the relaxing of restrictions at the Downing Street briefing.Mr Child told Sky News Portuguese hoteliers are desperate for custom and so room prices are not yet raising prices, evenairlines might bump up flight costs. Have your travel plans been affected by the pandemic  Let us know at webnews@mirrorGary Piazzon, founder of portertravel, praised the announcement, describing Portugal as the real winner here.Speaking to the Sun soon after the briefing, he said: “Data reveals that in the last hour, Google searches for ‘Holidays to Portugal’ have skyrocketed, up ,% when compared with ten minutes before the Transport Secretary’s announcement.Mr Piazzon said that searches for fellow green listers Israel and Gibraltar were also up ,% and %, respectively. “I agree with Grant Shapps in that travellers are crucial to rebuilding the UK economy and I really hope this is the all-important light at the end of the tunnel we’ve been waiting for, he added.It comes as Ryanair added extra flights to Portugal, with , seats to the likes of the Algarve, Lisbon and Porto for the summer holidays. Other countries to make the cut were Israel, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Brunei, Iceland and the Faroe Islands, and several small remote islands that are British Overseas Territories.However, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Brunei and the Faroe Islands wonapost actually be accepting British arrivals. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are yet to announce their international travel plans. As expected, Spain, France, Italy, Greece and the US were all left off the initial green list and given amber ratings meaning travellers will have to isolate on theirhome. Travel industry bosses have slammed the move as too cautious and detrimental to struggling tourism companies hit hard by the border closure. Critics have called for the Greek islands, the Canary Islands and the Balearic Islands to be added to the green list.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePrince Charles has just met his grandson Archie twice meaning there are few photos of them together, according to reports. The fact the Prince of Wales has seen so little of his fourth grandchild meant royal aides struggled to find a good photo to use as part of Archieaposs nd birthday message earlier this week, it is claimed.According to the Mail officials at the palace were left feeling uncomfortable because they didnapost have an up-to-date picture of Meghan and Harryaposs son Archie to accompany the posts.Instead they had to use photos from just after he was born or from his official christening. The paper even claims that Archie may have just met his Cambridge cousins - Prince George, seven, Princess Charlotte, six, and three-year-old Prince Loius - just the once. A source said: The truth is the Prince of Wales has barely seen his grandson twice since he was born. In fact every member of Harry’s family can easily count on one hand the number of times they saw Archie after he was born and before the family left the UK. It’s a very sad situation. The source reportedly stressed that no one is directly to blame for the lack of family connections. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex sensationally quit the royal family last year and moved first to Vancouver Island on Canadaaposs west coast and then to Los Angeles, where they now reside. The pandemic has meant that they have been unable to make social visits toto the UK although Harry was back in Windsor briefly for his grandfatheraposs funeral. The Queen and other family members have mostly had to make do with video calls.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Britons trying to enjoy a pint in a beer garden or an al fresco meal are being lashed by miserably wet and windy weather up and down the country.Up to ins of rain was expected in heavy, prolonged downpours in the Brecon Beacons in Wales, while snow was falling over high ground in northern England. A yellow warning for rain was issued for a large swathe of South Wales. Flood alerts were issued across the Swansea area and for the River Sow and River Penk near Stafford as levels increased following persistent heavy rainfall overnight and Saturday morning.The dreary conditions were likely to disrupt plans for many in England, where pubgoers and restaurant diners can only enjoy pints and meals outside due to the coronavirus lockdown.Is it raining heavily or snowing where you live  Send your photos of extreme weather to webnews@mirror.  The Met Office said rain in southern and western areas would be heavy over hills, and move northwards across most areas through the day.Drivers were told to prepare for dficult conditions and travel disruption on roads and motorways due to heavy rain and gales. In North Yorkshire and Cumbria, snow was falling in a number of places, including Tailbrigg Hill, near the border between the two counties.  Golfers, cyclists and joggers braved the conditions as golf courses and parks were waterlogged, and huge puddles formed on roads in places such as Brighton, East Sussex, and Wimbledon in south London. Parts of southern and eastern England could turn brighter and it could be milder and rather warm in the south-east. The evening was expected to be mild in most areas with some rain, especially in parts of Wales and western England. Showers in many places should turn lighter and more patchy later, the Met Office said. North-western and south-eastern parts of the UK will continue to see heavy rain at times on Sunday. Further downpours and a risk of thunderstorms are expected from Monday. A yellow warning for rain for South Wales, including Cardf and Swansea, was due to last until midnight. The Met Office warned: Wet and windy weather developing during Friday night will persist through Saturday. Rain will be heavy at times, especially Saturday morning. Rain may ease in some areas during the afternoon before becoming heavier and more persistent again during the evening.  to mm of rain may fall quite widely across the warning area and as much as  to mm is possible over parts of the Brecon Beacons. Natural Resources Wales had issued five flood alerts - for Rivers Llynfi and Ogmore, River Neath, Upper Tawe, Rivers Loughor and Amman, and Rivers Gwendraeths - as of am.  Englandaposs Environment Agency had issued a flood alert for the River Sow and River Penk near Stafford, saying flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin this morning It added: Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Met Office five-day weather forecast Saturday Rain in southern and western areas, heavy over hills, will move northwards across most areas. Northern Ireland brightening up with scattered showers, while parts of southern and eastern England should turn brighter. Windy but milder, rather warm in the south-east.

news uk-news vax-live-organiser-shares-how-"" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice The organiser of the Vax Live has shared how he managed to get Meghan Markle and Prince Harry involved - just by asking.Global Citizen CEO Hugh Evans said the royal couple jumped on board immediately as campaign chairs of Global Citizen’s Vax Live: The Concert to Reunite the World and were on the apossame pageapos. He said they didnapost need convincing, it was merely a conversation.Mr Evans told Variety at the concert taping on Sunday night at SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, Calornia. “They were so excited. They said, ‘We believe in the importance of vaccine equity.’For them, it was an easy decision to do the right thing because they were so passionate already. He said when he spoke to Meghan she suggested calling on he private sector to rally and for US businesses to step up, and so they got to work. “They’ve approached it with such sincerity and such leadership. I’ve been extremely impressed with their amazing commitment to the cause, Mr Evans said. Prince Harry received a rapturous response as he took to the stage of a vaccine fundraising concert in the US - but without his pregnant we Meghan. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex had both been set to join famous names from the worlds of music, film and politics at the Vax Live event in Calornia. But while Harry made his first public appearance since the funeral of his grandfather Prince Philip to address the crowd, his partner did not join him in person.He was given a standing ovation by the crowd, before giving a speech praising the selfless efforts of front line workers during the pandemic. Speaking to an animated crowd of only fully-vaccinated guests, the duke asked for vaccines to be distributed to everyone everywhere, while also saluting frontline medical workers both at the concert and around the world.  The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have called on Covid vaccine manufacturers to act with responsibility and leadership and increase their allocation of doses distributed to poorer parts of the world. Harry and Meghan have written an open letter to the chief executives of pharmaceutical companies like Pfizer, Moderna and AstraZeneca urging them to redouble their support for the UN-sponsored Covax programme. The couple have called on all firms to temporarily suspend intellectual property rights applied to Covid vaccines, and for a global public-private collaboration so production methods for the jabs can be shared. The Sussexesapos intervention into the global debate about the vaccine rollout comes on the second birthday of their son Archie, and separately they have asked those wanting to mark this to donate funds which will support Covax.  Harry and Meghan, writing in their roles as Vax Live campaign chairs, said: As of May , over % of the . billion vaccine doses administered globally have occurred in high and upper-middle-income countries while the very lowest income countries have administered just .%. As we are seeing in countries like India, the urgency to deliver doses now to save lives and stop the spread of Covid- is only increasing. Thataposs why it is imperative that we ensure equitable vaccine access globally so that people are protected, economies can recover, and this global pandemic can be brought to an end everywhere. Therefore we, the undersigned, stand with global citizens who want to see Covid- vaccine manufacturers act with extraordinary purpose, responsibility, and leadership in response to this equity crisis.  Harry and Meghanaposs letter is available for the public to sign on the website of the anti-poverty movement Global Citizen, and it calls on Moderna to move up your delivery schedule with Covax and increase the promised  volume to at least  million doses. It also urges Pfizer BioNTech to commit at least  million additional doses to Covax at a not-for-profit price and to deliver them as soon as possible this year. Covax was set up last year to try to establish fair access to the vaccines for poor and rich nations, but huge discrepancies have emerged. It has been reported that more than  million doses have been delivered through the system but more than £ billion is still needed to ensure most adults are immunised.  While the British Government is among the biggest donors to Covax, it has come under criticism for slashing the aid budget to . per cent of gross national income, despite the Conservative manesto pledging to keep it at . per cent. Marie Rumsby, UK country director for Global Citizen, said: The work of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex on the Vax Live campaign demonstrates how urgent the need is to act now and ensure everyone, everywhere has access to Covid- vaccines.

title: worshippers pelted eggs london mosque
story: NewsWorshippers pelted with eggs at London mosque in act of hatred during RamadanPoliticians condemned the incident at the Ilford Islamic Centre in London as a disgraceful act of hatred and violence that has no place in the community. Muslims are observing the holy month of RamadanmirrorShareCommentsByMike BediganChiara Fiorillo:,  MAY NewsThe incident happened at the Ilford Islamic Centre on Tuesday" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeWorshippers at a mosque in east London have been attacked with eggs, prompting a police investigation. The incident at the Ilford Islamic Centre happened this week, while the Muslim community continues to observe the holy month of Ramadan - which ends next week. Local politicians have condemned the incident as a “disgraceful act of hatred and violence” that has “no place” in the community. The politan Police said it received a report of racially aggravated criminal damage at around pm on Tuesday evening at a mosque in Albert Road, Ilford. The Federation of Redbridge Muslim Organisations tweeted that eggs and other items had been thrown at worshippers and that five people were hit, but none seriously injured. The Met said that so far there have been no arrests. Ahmed Nawaz, director and secretary of the centre, said the incident was “a shame” but the community remained strong. He told PA: “I was caught by surprise because leading up to this we had a very quiet and peaceful -odd nights, and then this happened. “We weren’t expecting it this kind of time in the period of reflection for everyone, having gone through Covid.” He added: “It’s a shamewe’re used to it. “We’re a strong community and we take it on the chin. It makes us weary rather than fearful.”  Mr Nawaz said police and local authorities had been “very supportive” following the incident but that attacks against the Muslim community were often “glossed over” in the media. “We just want to be treated like humans, just like everyone ,” he said. Sam Tarry, Labour MP for Ilford South, said: “I am shocked and saddened to hear of this Islamophobic attack against Ilford Mosque. “These disgraceful acts of violence and hatred have no place in Ilford, and I hope that the perpetrators face justice as soon as possible.” Jas Athwal, Labour leader of Redbridge Council, said the council would continue to work closely with police and that security in areas surrounding the mosque would be increased. “Racist incidents like this have no place in our borough and we will work with our friends and neighbours at Albert Road Mosque, and the police to ensure the safety of all worshippers.”

title: mum 15 delivers baby number
story: NewsMum-of- delivers baby number  - and they all have names beginning with CEXCLUSIVE: Patty Hernandez, , from Charlotte, North Carolina, has given all her children names beginning with C in honour of her husband Carlos, although she was struggling to think up a new one before the birth of her latest sonmirrorShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPatty Hernandez posing with her husband Carlos and their huge brood " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum-of- has delivered her th baby - and all of the children have names beginning with the letter aposCapos. Patty Hernandez, , from Charlotte, North Carolina, continued the unusual family tradition by naming her newborn Clayton. She named all of her children with the same first letter in honour of their -year-old dad Carlos. But Patty revealed that she and her husband had struggled to think up a new name beginning with aposCapos before their latest son was born. She told The Mirror: We couldnapost figure out a name and then Clayton just popped into my head. All the kids have names beginning with aposCapos and we wanted to keep that going. My husband is called Carlos... itaposs a tribute to him. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  The mum said her latest pregnancy was her toughest yet, although despite this she is still open to having more children. Patty, who runs her own cleaning company, said she feels like her huge family is a aposblessingapos from God. She added: God has blessed us with all these kids, I know some people donapost agree and there are nasty comments online but for us itaposs a big blessing. I never thought I would have a big family until I started having babies. Then I thought aposthis is cool, why not apos Itaposs really fun.  If God wants us to have another child we will have another one. Carlos was by his weaposs side on May  when she delivered Clayton, who weighed lbs and  ounces. The mum was  weeks pregnant when she gave birth - her longest pregnancy yet - and she is still in hospital now. All my other births have been before  weeks. He just didnapost want to come out, she said.  The other children are anxious to meet their little brother. Iaposve been in hospital since Tuesday. They induced me on Tuesday and he came out on Wednesday. Patty said most of the nurses at the hospital recognised her when she went in for the delivery. They were like aposyou were here last year, we see you every yearapos, she said. Patty and her husband currently spend an eye-watering £ on food for their children every fortnight, however she stressed they do not receive any government support.

Kat, who lives in the US, is a flight attendant and has been posting a number of plane secrets and tips on the video-sharing . She recently explained how passengers could get themselves free drinks and air miles when they travel and is now back with another clip. This time, sheaposs shared the reason why you rarely see flight attendants going through security with you. Kat explained: Have you ever been in the airport and you thought aposwhereaposs all the flight attendants and the pilots  Why are they not going through security apos Iaposm gonna tell you where we actually go. So, at most major airports, we have something thataposs known as K.C.M. or Known Crew Member and what this is, is when weaposre hired we get an extensive background check on us, we get our fingerprints done, itaposs a whole entire process. So we can actually go through a secret little door, show our badge, show our Known Crew Member, it gets scanned and we just walk right through, we donapost have to do security.

title: frozen fans dark theory kristoff
story: NewsFrozen fans dark theory about Kristoff and Svens friendship is ruining the film for peopleThe unbreakable friendship between Kristoff and his reindeer sidekick Sven in Disneys Frozen has been called into question by a fan who presented a disturbing theory about its originsmirrorShareCommentsByLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  MAY NewsKristoff and Sven appear to have the perfect friendship, right  " %, rgba, rgba, url" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your dayInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.SubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeFrozenaposs release in  saw it become a blockbuster hit as a family-friendly film with a soundtrack that your brain still plays on repeat whenever it gets the chance. When Snow Queen Elsa flees Arendelle after accidentally plunging the kingdom into internal winter, her sister Anna sets out on a mission to try and find her and break the icy spell. Anna enrols the help of mountaineer Kristoff and his reindeer sidekick Sven, who appear to have the perfect friendship that started when they were infant and calve, developing an unbreakable bond. But one Frozen fan has a theory that the beginnings of their relationship wasnapost all the rainbows and butterflies it might seem - and it could change the way you watch the film forever. Posting on Reddit, they said: Iaposm probably slow but have only just noticed that in Frozen, Kristoffaposs coat is made from fur. Andyou look closer at the pics the fur part seems to be reindeer. I donapost think it can be wolf cos the pelt is too big. That makes it a bit awkward, though, that Kristoffaposs best friend is a reindeer and heaposs actually wearing his skin. But in the context of the story, it all fits together. The ice harvesters must have killed Svenaposs mother, leaving a baby Sven for Kristoff to look after, and giving him the pelt to wear. This explains why Sven is so close to Kristoff too, and why Kristoff still wears the same pelt. The smell reminds Sven of his mum. Yep, the theory is that Kristoff is wearing the skin of Svenaposs murdered mother.

news weird-news man-plays-slimy-creature-found-"ByLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  May A man had a very lucky escape after he filmed himself handling and even licking a aposslimyapos creature he stumbled across on the beach - completely ignorant to the danger it posed. The clip shows a sea animal washed up on the beach, with a transparent balloon-like float and blue colouring, as well as long strands of tentacles coming off the bottom.TikTok user Alexa_reed says: Look guys, a jellyfish is still here, while prodding at it with his finger, commenting on how cold and slimy it is before adding: Iaposm going to pick it up.He pinches it between his fingers and says: This is how it looks like. Yes, itaposs a jellyfish, look how big it is. And itaposs still moving, oh my god, Iaposm going to lick it. But what he seemingly didnapost know was that the creature was actually a Portuguese Man Oapos War, nicknamed the aposfloating terrorapos, which has been known to kill humans. Although its rare for humans to be killed by the venom the animal uses to paralyse and kill prey, the sting can cause shocking welts on exposed skin, leaving victims in excruciating pain for days afterwards.The post was replied to by Mndiaye_, who shares informative videos about nature, and warned others not to copy what they had seen, saying: This is why women live longer than men, s*** like this.That is not a jellyfish, itaposs a Portuguese Man Oapos War, also known as the bluebottle, also known as the floating terror.  Itaposs a species of siphonophore armed with millions of explosive stinging cells powerful enough to make Nemo an orphan and occasionally turn a person into past tense. This Man Oapos War is responsible for up to , stings a year in Australia alone and the venom can cause excruciating pain for up to three days, leaving a nasty, whip-like welt as a souvenir. But honestly, youaposre luckythataposs all you get because the venom can trigger an allergic-like reaction that results in throat-swelling, heart issues and dficulty breathing, as you suffocate, possibly to death.
